article.title: SpaceX Targets Mid-March for Starship Flight 12, the First Flight of Block 3 V3 Hardware Powered by 33 Raptor 3 Engines
article.summary: Flight 12 will debut the production-representative Block 3 Starship and Super Heavy Booster 19, equipped with 33 Raptor 3 engines and launching from Starbase's newly completed second pad.
article.body_markdown:
## Overview

SpaceX is preparing for the twelfth test flight of its Starship-Super Heavy system, targeting mid-March 2026 for what will be the program's most significant hardware upgrade to date. Flight 12 will debut the Block 3 (V3) generation of both vehicles — Super Heavy Booster 19 and Ship 39 — along with 33 next-generation Raptor 3 engines and a new second launch pad at Starbase in South Texas.

Elon Musk announced the six-week target on January 26, placing the earliest possible launch around March 9, according to [SpaceNews](https://spacenews.com/spacex-plans-next-starship-test-flight-in-march/) and [Space.com](https://www.space.com/space-exploration/launches-spacecraft/spacex-targeting-mid-march-for-1st-flight-of-bigger-more-powerful-starship-version-3-elon-musk-says). FAA licensing and ongoing hardware testing remain the primary variables affecting the final date.

## Block 3: The Production-Representative Design

The V3 architecture is not an experimental prototype. According to [SpaceNews](https://spacenews.com/spacex-plans-next-starship-test-flight-in-march/), SpaceX's launch vice president described it as "really going to be our production rocket," signaling a shift from iterative development hardware to the configuration SpaceX intends to manufacture and operate at scale.

Super Heavy Booster 19 completed cryogenic proof testing — in which liquid oxygen is loaded to near-flight pressure levels to validate structural integrity — at SpaceX's Massey's Outpost test site in early February 2026, as reported by [NASASpaceFlight.com](https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2025/12/flight-12-vehicles-2026/). Engine installation of 33 Raptor 3 engines followed. Ship 39, the upper stage, was rolled out from MegaBay 2 to Massey's on February 26 for its own pressure and cryogenic proof tests, according to [Tesla Oracle](https://www.teslaoracle.com/2026/02/27/spacex-prepares-for-flight-12-starship-39-prelaunch-testing-at-starbase-the-first-v3-starship-starbase-updates/).

## Raptor 3: More Thrust, Fewer Parts

Each of the 33 Raptor 3 engines fitted to Booster 19 produces 280 metric tons of thrust at sea level — a figure SpaceX confirmed publicly on its official channels. The vacuum variant generates 306 metric tons, making it the most powerful methane-fueled rocket engine ever flown. The engine achieves greater thrust while being lighter and mechanically simpler than the Raptor 2 it replaces, using internalized secondary flow paths and regenerative cooling to eliminate the external heat shield that previous variants required.

For Ship 39, the fully tiled heat shield spans the entire vehicle and all four flaps are installed, per [Tesla Oracle](https://www.teslaoracle.com/2026/02/27/spacex-prepares-for-flight-12-starship-39-prelaunch-testing-at-starbase-the-first-v3-starship-starbase-updates/). Together, Booster 19 and Ship 39 constitute the first complete Block 3 stack.

## Second Pad Debut

Flight 12 will launch from Starbase's second orbital pad, which SpaceX recently brought into service. The debut of Pad 2 increases launch cadence flexibility and provides redundancy at the facility. SpaceX has conducted water deluge tests at the new pad's flame trench — an acoustic suppression system designed to neutralize heat and sound from 33 Raptor engines firing simultaneously.

For this flight, neither the booster nor the upper stage is expected to be caught by the mechazilla arm; both are planned to splashdown in the ocean, according to the Federal Communications Commission license approved for the mission.

## NASA's Artemis Stakes

Flight 12 carries programmatic weight beyond SpaceX's own development timeline. NASA's Human Landing System for the Artemis III crewed lunar landing relies on a Starship variant that must demonstrate in-orbit propellant transfer — a capability that requires refueling Starship in low Earth orbit from tanker spacecraft before any crewed Moon mission can proceed. While Flight 12 will not attempt actual cryogenic fuel transfer, it will validate the docking hardware, propellant management systems, and structural interfaces that such operations require. NASA's acting administrator for exploration cited V3's capabilities as critical when commenting on the early 2026 launch to [SpaceNews](https://spacenews.com/spacex-plans-next-starship-test-flight-in-march/).

## What We Don't Know

The FAA's issuance of a communications license dated April 5 through October 5, 2026 — rather than one beginning in early March — suggests the agency may not finalize launch authorization on the timeline Musk indicated in January. SpaceX has previously slipped planned Starship windows due to regulatory delays, hardware findings during testing, or both. No static fire test of the fully stacked Block 3 vehicle has been confirmed as complete, and any anomaly during Ship 39's cryogenic proof tests could push the window further. Mission-level objectives for Flight 12 beyond hardware validation and splashdown recovery have not been publicly detailed by SpaceX.
